awd_titl_txt: Development of Group 9 Transition Metal Catalysts for Hydrocarbon Functionalization
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division is funding Professor T. Brent Gunnoe of the University of Virginia to study the development of catalysts that can selectively convert hydrocarbons, compounds that only contain hydrogen and carbon atoms, into more complex compounds.  Hydrocarbons from fossil resources form the foundation of the chemical industry and the energy sector. Recent years have seen an increase in access to vast amounts of domestic natural gas reserves; however, with current technological infrastructure the ability to transport natural gas economically is limited and therefore much natural gas in the U.S. and around the world remains "stranded" and unusable. Also, despite years of development, chemical processes that convert hydrocarbons into higher value chemicals often suffer from low selectivity for a desired compound and the requirement of high temperatures and pressures. Thus, new catalysts for alkane functionalization are essential for use of natural gas, and other hydrocarbons, as a precursor to new chemicals and transportation fuel. This research project is also providing training to undergraduate and graduate students to enable a future generation of scientists to work in the area of catalysis as it relates to the efficient use of fossil resources. The PI has also participated in several outreach and workshop events hosted by the University of Virginia's "More Than the Score" program, the Darden School of Business, and the "Car of the Future Summit."

Professor Gunnoe is synthesizing and studying group 9 transition metal complexes for the catalytic functionalization of hydrocarbons. This project builds on preliminary work in the Gunnoe group that demonstrated the ability of novel rhodium complexes to activate the carbon-hydrogen bonds of hydrocarbons under acidic conditions. These results are being extended to a detailed study of all steps in the desired catalytic cycles, including the carbon-hydrogen activation step (both arenes and alkanes), oxidation of the transition metal hydrocarbyl complex, and reductive functionalization of the metal-hydrocarbyl ligand. Reactions in acidic media are being targeted that yield oxy-functionalized compounds such as esters. One objective seeks to understand how to rationally design catalysts based upon cobalt, rhodium and iridium to optimize the rate of carbon-hydrogen activation in acidic solvent. A second thrust seeks to develop and understand optimization of reductive functionalization in acidic solvent. The third objective combines these individual steps into catalytic processes for oxidative hydrocarbon functionalization.

por.por_cntn:
Hydrocarbons, molecules that are comprised of only carbon and hydrogen, are the starting material for greater than 90% of the chemical industry's products including plastics, agricultural products and pharmaceuticals. Despite the maturity of this industry, many processes for the conversion of hydrocarbons to higher valuable materials consume substantial energy and generate chemical waste. The design of more efficient processes for hydrocarbon conversions could have substantial positive benefit both economically as well as environmentally while conserving precious carbon-based fossil resources.

One strategy to convert hydrocarbons into higher value and useful materials is to use a catalyst. For the conversion of hydrocarbons, catalysts serve to break carbon-hydrogen (C-H) bonds and to make new bonds that generate desired new chemicals. Current catalytic methods for hydrocarbon functionalization typically involve multi-step and energy intensive processes, and the increasing global demand for fossil resources in combination with mounting pressure to reduce environmental impact render the development of more efficient methods for hydrocarbon processing a critical need. New molecular catalysts offer the opportunity to achieve reactions that functionalize hydrocarbons with high selectivity and low waste production and energy consumption. But, to realize these opportunities improved understanding of how to design new molecular catalysts to control the energetics of key reactions in overall processes is critically important.

This project was focused on new understanding of how to design the catalyst active site (that is, the site that is responsible for bond breaking and bond formation) to optimize for desired chemical conversions of hydrocarbons. Specifically, we elucidated new strategies 1) to optimize catalytic breaking of C-H bonds using catalysts based on copper and rhodium, 2) to facilitate the formation of new bonds using rhodium catalysts, and 3) to catalyze hydrocarbon functionalization reactions using new iridium catalysts. 

This award supported the research of five graduate (Ph.D.) students and one undergraduate student. These students developed expertise in an array of experimental skills, received extensive safety training, and participated in programs to enhance their professional development. Three of the graduate students have completed their Ph.D. and are now employed either in an academic position or by a company in the chemical or pharmaceutical industry. Two graduate students remain in our Ph.D. program and are making progress toward completion of their degree. The undergraduate student is now working toward completion of her Ph.D. at another institution and was a recipient of a prestigious NSF Graduate Fellowship. The students disseminated the results of their research through presentations at scientific conferences, in their theses and through peer reviewed publications.
